Award.AwardTitle: Measuring next generation science instruction using tablet-based teacher portfolios

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The investigators will build and study an electronic, tablet-based teaching portfolio system that can be used to assess middle school science instruction and teachers. The tablet system will contain examples of instructional materials, student work, quizzes, and audio and video taken from classrooms. Teachers will be able to annotate the materials that they include in their electronic teaching portfolios. An electronic portfolio enables a comprehensive set of measures and evidence of teacher effectiveness, including the use of multi-media, something non-electronic portfolios cannot do. The tablet system is expected to become a more effective system for the assessment of teaching when compared to non-electronic forms of portfolios and labor intensive classroom observations. In addition, the electronic portfolio will have the added benefit of promoting teacher professional learning. These outcomes mean more efficient, ongoing, and better documented teaching assessment. The system will be consistent with the priorities established in the Next Generation Science Standards.

The researchers will partner with the Los Angeles Unified School District in piloting the tablet with 40 volunteer teachers. Data on student outcomes, teacher knowledge, and teaching practice will be used to cross validate the tablet measures. Quantitative measures will be enhanced by a set of interviews with teachers. In addition to publications, the investigators will make all of the materials, including source code and measures, available as open source on the web.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Measuring Next Generation Science Instruction Using Tablet-Based Teacher Portfolios project developed and investigated the use of a new digital portfolio to monitor, assess, and improve instruction in middle school science classrooms. The overall goal of the project was to develop, deploy, and evaluate an electronic teacher portfolio based on modern tablet technology for use by middle school science teachers to document instruction and assess the degree to which it is aligned with conceptual aspects of the Framework for K-12 Science Education and the Next Generation Science Standards (NGSS). To address this overarching goal, we engaged in the following major activities: 1) Developed an electronic portfolio application for Android and iOS systems and a web-based review portal; 2) Developed a set of Dimensions and corresponding 5-point rubrics that model effective instruction drawing on the NGSS and relevant literature; 3) Conducted a mixed methods validation study to investigate whether the scoring rubrics and rating protocol provide reliable and valid measures of science instruction; and 4) Piloted the use of the digital portfolio system within a professional learning community (PLC) to explore if and how the system can support meaningful professional learning for science teachers.

 

Findings from the reliability study indicated that trained raters using the Dimension-based rubrics produced scores that reliably reflect important aspects of quality instruction in science aligned to the NGSS. For a number of dimensions (including the Overall Quality rating), adequate to strong reliability coefficients (ranging from .67 - .89) indicate that portfolio ratings were able to differentiate instructional practice of varying levels. However, for some Dimensions, particularly the content accuracy of teachers’ practice and the quality of feedback provided by the teacher, low reliability (.28 and .61, respectively) revealed misalignment between rubrics and portfolio contents. The former misalignment was likely minimal instances of content inaccuracies and the latter from teachers not providing many student samples with their feedback, as directed. A factor analysis revealed a unidimensional structure underlaying the 11 Dimensions, a somewhat expected finding considering the deep conceptual connections of the Dimensions within the NGSS framework.

 

Additional analyses indicated that trained raters’ ratings correlated significantly with the ratings of master scorers, suggesting that raters with some background science content can be trained to rate and/or provide feedback on the portfolios. Little correlation was found between portfolio ratings and alternative measures of teacher knowledge and practice.

 

In addition to the measurement study, a small pilot study explored whether, when, and how a group of middle school science teachers used the e-QIS system in the context of a year-long PLC. Interviews with the teachers identified two major advantages for using the digital portfolio as a central tool in the PLC: 1) the portfolio provided a structured opportunity for the collection of and reflection on artifacts of student engagement in science learning – an opportunity in which it can be difficult for teachers to engage without a formal structure, and 2) the Dimensions of Quality Instruction in Science provided a framework for analyzing the artifacts and better understanding a continuum of instructional practice focused on maximizing students’ engagement in 3-D science learning.

 

Video analysis of the PLC sessions reflected the affordances and limitations of the digital portfolio. First, the structure of the portfolio and the potential for capturing multi-media artifacts resulted in PLCs that were focused on content and disciplinary science teaching practice. This finding is important as previous literature indicates that many traditional PLCs spend significant time talking about elements of teaching (e.g. classroom management) unrelated to student learning. Second, we found that the e-QIS system was essential in focusing the conversation on content, but not sufficient for ensuring the interrogation of practice. Participating teachers used collaborative time to talk about evidence of student engagement in science core ideas and practices, but the resulting discussion reflected more “show and tell” than an analysis of how the learning environment influenced students’ ideas about the content or how evidence from the classroom would inform future instructional decisions.

 

Ultimately, this project expanded our understanding of how teachers can use digital portfolios that include multi-media capacity and what elements of next generation science instruction are more reliably captured with these tools. The Dimensions will provide future scholars and teacher educators with a framework for thinking about high-quality instruction and findings from the PLC study point to needed work in optimizing the analytical work of teachers who use classroom artifacts as the foundation for professional growth. In addition to these intellectual merits, the development of the open-source digital portfolio and web-based review portal can be used for teacher education, on-going professional learning, and teacher evaluation. The forty teachers who participated in at least one aspect of this project also had opportunities for reflecting on their own science teaching.
